member.name: T:Burrow.AsyncSubscriptionOption`1
member.summary:
Provide options to asynchronously subscribe to a queue, the messages will not be automatically acked
You have to use the returned object to ack/nack the message when finish

member.name: T:Burrow.ConnectionString
member.summary:
Parses a connection string for the values required to connect to a RabbitMQ broker instance.
Connection string should look something like this: host=192.168.1.1;port=5672;virtualHost=MyVirtualHost;username=MyUsername;password=MyPassword

member.name: T:Burrow.Global
member.summary: A global class where you can set settings that control how the library works

member.name: F:Burrow.Global.DefaultTaskCreationOptionsProvider
member.summary:
When the MessageHandler handles the message using the callback, it will create a Task (TPL) for it. So this instance will help the MessageHandler to determine which type of Thread to create, either from Threadpool or a dedicated Thread The default value of this is an implementation that based on the available amount of worker threads in Threadpool to return the proper TaskCreationOption
In Win32, the MaxWorker is 1023 while the number is quite high in Win64 bit. So if your app is running as 64 bits, you probably need to call ThreadPool.SetMaxThreads() to a proper number or simply change the Global.DefaultTaskCreationOptionsProvider func to return TaskCreationOptions.LongRunning
The reason for this complexity is sometime your Task/ThreadPool is queued but cannot be started, probably the main application itself was creating so many threads, or the ThreadPool is completly full or many workers have been queued and that problem can block everything

member.name: F:Burrow.Global.DefaultConsumerBatchSize
member.summary: The higher the number is, the more threads a tunnel will create to consume messages in the queue. If set to 1, it means the messages will be consumed sequently This value is used by the TunnelFactory when it creates a RabbitTunnel This value is NOLONGER used to call IModel.BasicQos, if you want to do so, use PreFetchSize instead

members.member:
This value is also used to call IModel.BasicQos if the prefetch size is not provided when subscribing to the queue.It'll set the maximum amount of messages stay on the Unacknowledged list when they are consumed
If you app decides not to ack the message immediately but just queueing everything received from Burrow.NET and ack later once they're finished, you will not get morethan this number of messages in your internal queue because RabbitMQ.Client basically has a waithanler to block the consuming thread, only this number of messages can be dequeued. If this is a potential problem, you have to ack atleast a message to receive a new one from RabbitMQ

member.name: F:Burrow.Global.DefaultPersistentMode
member.summary: Set to true will save the message to disk when it's published, default is true. If its value is false, the messages will be removed when the server is restarted. This value is used by the default TunnelFactory when it create a RabbitTunnel

member.name: F:Burrow.Global.DefaultErrorQueueName
member.summary:
The error queue name where error messages will be published to.
You don't have to create this queue, the library will create it when there is an error

member.name: F:Burrow.Global.DefaultErrorExchangeName
member.summary:
The error exchange name where error messages will be published to
You don't have to create this exchange, the library will create it when there is an error

member.name: F:Burrow.Global.ConsumerDisposeTimeoutInSeconds
member.summary: The default value in seconds for a consumer to wait until all pending messages are processed. It's related to https://github.com/vanthoainguyen/Burrow.NET/pull/6

member.summary:
Create a asynchronous IBasicConsumer which can spawn 1 or more threads to consume messages from the queue, this consumer should NOT ack the messages after handling them.
Indeed, the system should act the messages later based on the data provided in MessageDeliverEventArgs

member.name: P:Burrow.ITunnel.DedicatedPublishingChannel
member.summary:
Public access to the channel object which is used for publishing messages
for those who wish to use Confirms (aka Publisher Acknowledgements) can confirmSelect() or even txSelect() the channel
Reference: http://www.rabbitmq.com/confirms.html
Reference: http://www.rabbitmq.com/blog/2011/02/10/introducing-publisher-confirms/

member.name: M:Burrow.ITunnel.Publish``1(``0)
member.summary: Publish a message to an exchange defined by route finder. The message will eventually be routed to the queue(s) by the routing key resolved by route finder
member.param: A message to publish

member.name: M:Burrow.ITunnel.Publish``1(``0,System.String)
member.summary: Publish a message with a routing key to an exchange defined by route finder. The message will eventually be routed to the queue(s) by the routing key
member.param: A message to publish

member.name: M:Burrow.ITunnel.Publish``1(``0,System.Collections.Generic.IDictionary{System.String,System.Object})
member.summary:
Use this method to publish a message with custome headers to a "headers" exchange defined by route finder.
The message will be published to that exchange with a routing key resolved by the route finder
So if the target exchange is Direct or Fanout, the customHeaders have no value here and should be ignored by RabbitMQ.
This method should be used when you're sure that you're publishing to a "headers" exchange
member.param: A message to publish
If you're publishing to a Header exchange, this method allows you to put your header parameters

member.name: M:Burrow.ITunnel.Subscribe``1(Burrow.SubscriptionOption{``0})
member.summary:
Subscribe to queue with provided option, the message WILL be automatically acked after the callback executed
You DON'T have to use the returned object to ack/nack because it's done automatically for you

member.name: M:Burrow.ITunnel.SubscribeAsync``1(Burrow.AsyncSubscriptionOption{``0})
member.summary:
Subscribe to queue with provided option, the message WON'T be automatically acked after the callback executed
You have to use the returned object to ack/nack the message when finish

member.name: M:Burrow.ITunnel.Subscribe``1(System.String,System.Action{``0})
member.summary: Subscribe to queue by using subscriptionName, the message will be automatically acked once the callback executed
member.param: SubscriptionName together with the type of Message can be used to define the queue name in IRouteFinder
A callback method to process received message

member.name: M:Burrow.ITunnel.Subscribe``1(System.String,System.Action{``0,Burrow.MessageDeliverEventArgs})
member.summary: Subscribe to queue by using subscriptionName, the message will be not automatically acked
member.param: SubscriptionName together with the type of Message can be used to define the queue name in IRouteFinder
A callback method to process received message
member.returns:
Subscription object which can be used to send Ack or NoAck message to server by the delivery tag received in the callback
Because this is async method, you must ensure that the subscription is created before using it to ack/nack messages

member.name: M:Burrow.ITunnel.SubscribeAsync``1(System.String,System.Action{``0},System.Nullable{System.UInt16})
member.summary: Subscribe to queue by using subscriptionName, the message will be automatically acked once the callback executed
member.param: SubscriptionName together with the type of Message can be used to define the queue name in IRouteFinder
A callback method to process received message
The number of threads to process messages, Default is Global.DefaultConsumerBatchSize

member.name: M:Burrow.ITunnel.SubscribeAsync``1(System.String,System.Action{``0,Burrow.MessageDeliverEventArgs},System.Nullable{System.UInt16})
member.summary: Subscribe to queue by using subscriptionName, the message won't be automatically acked
member.param: SubscriptionName together with the type of Message can be used to define the queue name in IRouteFinder
A callback method to process received message
The number of threads to process messages, Default is Global.DefaultConsumerBatchSize
member.returns:
Subscription object which can be used to send Ack or NoAck message to server by the delivery tag received in the callback
Because this is async method, you must ensure that the subscription is created before using it to ack/nack messages

member.name: T:Burrow.DefaultTaskCreationOptionProvider
member.summary: This class try to find available Threads in Pool to determine whether using ThreadPool or Dedicated Thread by returning a proper TaskCreationOptions In Win32, the MaxWorker is 1023 where the number is quite high in Win64 bit. So if your app is running as a 64 bit app, you properly need to call ThreadPool.SetMaxThreads() to a proper number or simply change the Global.DefaultTaskCreationOptionsProvider func to return TaskCreationOptions.LongRunning which eventually make TPL create dedicated Thread instead of queue a worker in ThreadPool

member.summary: Provide options to subscribe to a queue

member.name: P:Burrow.SubscriptionOption`1.BatchSize
member.summary: The number of threads to process messaages, default is 1

member.name: P:Burrow.SubscriptionOption`1.QueuePrefetchSize
member.summary: Specify the message prefetch size for the subscribed queue

member.name: P:Burrow.SubscriptionOption`1.RouteFinder
member.summary: Optional, if not set the RouteFinder from the Tunnel object will be used
